title: Abraham and Abimelech
shortSummary: Genesis 20 recounts Abraham's sojourn in Gerar where he again presents Sarah as his sister, leading to Abimelech taking her. God intervenes through a dream to protect Sarah and preserve His covenant with Abraham, highlighting divine protection and the importance of integrity before God.
timeline: c. 2100 BC - Patriarchal Period during Abraham's lifetime

keyCharacters.name: Abraham
keyCharacters.description: The patriarch who journeys to Gerar and, out of fear, misrepresents Sarah as his sister.

keyCharacters.name: Sarah
keyCharacters.description: Abraham's wife, whose identity is concealed to protect Abraham but causes a crisis in Gerar.

keyCharacters.name: Abimelech
keyCharacters.description: King of Gerar who unknowingly takes Sarah, but is warned by God in a dream and acts righteously to restore her.

definitions.definition: To live temporarily in a place; Abraham temporarily resided in Gerar.
The quality of being honest and having strong moral principles, as demonstrated by Abimelech’s innocence.
A person chosen by God to speak on His behalf; Abraham is called a prophet who prays for Abimelech.
A phrase indicating protection or a means to prevent harm or reproach, as Abimelech gives silver to Sarah.

outline.heading: Abraham’s Sojourn and Deception
outline.description: Abraham moves to Gerar and again claims Sarah is his sister, setting the stage for conflict and divine intervention.

outline.heading: God’s Warning to Abimelech
outline.description: God appears to Abimelech in a dream, warning him about Sarah and commanding him to restore her to Abraham, demonstrating God’s protective care.

outline.heading: Abimelech’s Confrontation with Abraham
outline.description: Abimelech confronts Abraham about his deception; Abraham explains his fear and partial truth, revealing human frailty and divine mercy.

outline.heading: Restoration and Blessing
outline.description: Abimelech restores Sarah to Abraham, compensates him, and God heals Abimelech’s household, reaffirming God’s covenant faithfulness.

application: Trust God’s protection even when circumstances seem threatening, knowing He can intervene on our behalf.
Practice honesty and integrity in all situations, recognizing the consequences of deception.
Pray for others, especially those who have wronged us, as Abraham interceded for Abimelech’s healing.
Respond to God’s warnings and correction promptly to avoid judgment and experience His mercy.

keyVerses.text: But God came to Abimelech in a dream by night, and said to him, Behold, thou art but a dead man, for the woman which thou hast taken; for she is a man's wife.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s direct intervention to protect His covenant promises and uphold righteousness.

keyVerses.text: Now therefore restore the man his wife; for he is a prophet, and he shall pray for thee, and thou shalt live: and if thou restore her not, know thou that thou shalt surely die, thou, and all that are thine.
keyVerses.significance: God identifies Abraham as a prophet and emphasizes the power of intercessory prayer for mercy and life.

keyVerses.text: So Abraham prayed unto God: and God healed Abimelech, and his wife, and his maidservants; and they bare children.
keyVerses.significance: This verse demonstrates the effectiveness of Abraham’s prayer and God’s blessing in restoring fertility and life.
